evidence_span: Significant differences in grain morphology were observed between samples oxidized in the autoclave and in-reactor, with shorter, less well-aligned monoclinic grains and more tetragonal grains in the neutron-irradiated samples

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk1
evidence_span: Neutron irradiation seems to have little effect on promoting fast oxidation or dissolution of $\beta$ -niobium precipitates but encourages the dissolution of iron from Laves-phase precipitates

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk1
evidence_span: An electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) analysis of the oxidation state of niobium in $\beta$ -niobium SPPs in the oxide revealed the fully oxidized ${ \mathsf { N b } } ^ { 5 + }$ state in SPPs deep into the oxide but ${ \mathsf { N b } } ^ { 2 + }$ in crystalline SPPs near the metal-oxide interface

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk1
evidence_span: An electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) analysis of the oxidation state of niobium in $\beta$ -niobium SPPs in the oxide revealed the fully oxidized ${ \mathsf { N b } } ^ { 5 + }$ state in SPPs deep into the oxide but ${ \mathsf { N b } } ^ { 2 + }$ in crystalline SPPs near the metal-oxide interface

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk1
evidence_span: The combined thickness of the ZrO suboxide and oxygen-saturated layers at the metaloxide interface correlated well to the instantaneous oxidation rate

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk1
evidence_span: Porosity in the oxide had a major influence on the overall rate of oxidation, and there was more porosity in the rapidly oxidizing annealed Zr-1.oNb alloy than in either the recrystallized alloy or the similar alloy exposed to neutron irradiation

evidence_span: Recrystallized $\mathrm { Z r - 1 . 0 N b }$ was oxidized for up to 540 days in a static autoclave in simulated primary water with 2 wt. ppm lithium added in the form of lithium hydroxide and 1,000 wt. ppm boron added as boric acid at a pressure of approximately $1 8 ~ \mathrm { M P a }$ at $3 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: For recrystallized $\mathrm { Z r - 1 . 0 N b }$ alloys, six samples were chosen for detailed study. The 3-day sample represented the very beginning of the corrosion process at which the sample had a very fast oxidation rate.

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The TEM bright-field (BF) image in Fig. 2a-1 shows that the right side of the oxide has a uniform thickness of $0 . 6 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: on the left the oxide becomes uneven with the thickest part greater than $1 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The 120-day sample (not shown) represented the early stage of oxidation with an average oxide thickness of $2 . 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The 225-day sample (also not shown) represented a stage before the first transition when the oxide had grown to approximately $2 . 5 { - } 2 . 7 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The 360-day sample was taken at approximately the first transition, and the oxide thickness grew to approximately $3 . 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Fig. 2b-1)

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The 540-day sample (also not shown) represented the second transition with an average oxide length of $5 . 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The 585-day sample was well past the second transition. As seen from the STEM high-angular annual dark-field (STEM HAADF) image in Fig. 2c-1, after the second layer of cracks, another approximately $9 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { n m } }$ of oxide grew during the 45 days in deuterated water. The oxide thickness was approximately $6 . 1 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: For the annealed $\mathrm { Z r - 1 . 0 N b }$ alloys, four samples were chosen for detailed study.

evidence_span: The 3-day sample represented the early stage of oxidation (Fig. 2a-1), and the oxide thickness ranged from 0.5 to $0 . 9 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

evidence_span: The 46-day sample was just before the first transition. The oxide in Fig. 2b-2 ranged in thickness from 2.5 to $4 . 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$

evidence_span: The 91-day sample (not shown) was after the first transition and had an an average thickness of $5 . 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1597-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_18th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: The second type is larger in size, has a lower number density, and tends to rapidly become amorphous once incorporated into the growing oxide.
